quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Product leadership is the type of role where if you are not in control of the voices in your head, they will eat you alive.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for the internal resilience required to lead in high-pressure product roles.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If they come to me and they're upset, I try to focus them less around how you litigate another person's impression of you and more on what is the action that you can take to counter program the narrative that you are afraid that this other person has of you. What are you going to do next to demonstrate that you are the person that you know yourself to be?
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Actionable coaching approach: shift from debating perceptions to taking concrete next steps that reshape the narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I would really love it if more people were like, "Screw it. I'm going to do something that's probably going to fail. It's important and it's worth doing and I'm going to do it well."
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A contrarian push toward high-importance, high-risk work—done with craft—even when failure is likely.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: People think that the game is all about influencing the CEO, influencing the people around them. You come up thinking like you're the protagonist. But in the story of work, you are probably not the protagonist. You're not special.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A reframing that challenges ego-driven influence tactics and encourages practitioners to operate with humility and realism.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical expectation-setting reminder to plan for enterprise requirements as your SaaS matures.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a build-vs-buy heuristic: choose tooling that minimizes cognitive load and speeds delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concise model for evaluating authorization systems: scale + flexibility for complex permissioning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What sets Persona apart is its configurability. Every company has different needs depending on its industry use cases, risk tolerance, and user demographics.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A useful lens for identity/fraud tooling selection: optimize for configurability aligned to risk and user mix.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Persona's orchestration tools automate your identity process so that you can fight rapidly shifting fraud and meet new waves of regulation.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway that automation/orchestration is key to keeping up with evolving fraud and compliance demands.

quotes.topic_title: Why resilience matters more than ever
quotes.text: And so I think all managers now really need to be able to lead their teams through uncertainty, through fear, through hard things.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A clear, actionable expectation for modern managers: resilience leadership is now a core part of the job.

quotes.topic_title: Why resilience matters more than ever
quotes.text: And I love the concept of taking a punch. I've got a couple other tools that I like to use, but I think it can teach people how to thrive in these environments.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Introduces “taking a punch” as a practical resilience model aimed at thriving (not just surviving) in high-setback environments.

quotes.topic_title: Why resilience matters more than ever
quotes.text: And the more people are fearful about the future of their careers or the future of work, I think the more they gravitate toward things that they feel like they're likely to succeed at.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A counterintuitive dynamic: fear pushes teams toward safer work, which can reduce ambition and innovation.

quotes.topic_title: Why resilience matters more than ever
quotes.text: but I would really love it if more people were like, "Screw it. I'm going to do something that's probably going to fail and it's important and it's worth doing and I'm going to do it well."
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A memorable call to pursue high-importance work even when failure is likely—an explicit mindset shift toward courageous execution.

quotes.topic_title: Counter-programming after you take a punch
quotes.text: I try to focus them less around whatever happened and how you litigate another person's impression of you based on something that has already happened, and more on what is the action that you can take next to counter program the narrative that you are afraid that this other person has of you.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A practical reframe for post-mistake anxiety: stop debating perceptions and shift to a concrete next action that changes the story.

quotes.topic_title: Counter-programming after you take a punch
quotes.text: When you do that, I think more than often, more often than not, you come off as just looking defensive and you start obsessing over things that you don't actually have control over, which is what another person thinks of you.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that trying to “correct the record” often backfires by signaling defensiveness and fixating on uncontrollables.

quotes.topic_title: Counter-programming after you take a punch
quotes.text: And so I always ask myself in these moments, what is one thing that I can do, small, that will demonstrate the opposite of what I'm afraid this person thinks of me?
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A memorable, repeatable prompt that turns ego-injury into a specific behavioral move anyone can take immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Counter-programming after you take a punch
quotes.text: And so I very quickly just sent her a note that said, "Wanted to build on this idea you had today. I really liked that idea, by the way. I saw this article, I saw this research about this other emerging thing, sports betting, and I think it'd be really interesting for us to start tracking that because we could maybe draw some correlations between people stress. We have a stress monitor in Whoop. We can track their stress. We could draw interesting correlations between betting behaviors and stress levels."
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Concrete example of “counter-programming” by quickly demonstrating seriousness and curiosity rather than explaining or apologizing at length.

quotes.topic_title: Counter-programming after you take a punch
quotes.text: I challenge it and I say, "First of all, I don't think there's evidence for that. Is there evidence for that? And even if there is, it doesn't really matter. What's something that you could do to show them that it's not true because you know it's not true?"
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A manager script for interrupting negative spirals and redirecting toward evidence-checking plus an action that proves capability.

quotes.topic_title: CBT behavioral activation applied to management
quotes.text: And the misconception is I'll feel better and then I'll act. And the thing that therapists try to teach people, they're working with them in therapy is I will act and then I will feel better.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A crisp, counterintuitive reframing of motivation: behavior leads emotion, not the other way around.

quotes.topic_title: CBT behavioral activation applied to management
quotes.text: And a lot of the work is in how you help people identify specific actions that they can take that will reliably lift their mood.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Turns an abstract mental-health concept into an actionable management practice: define small, reliable actions that change state.

quotes.topic_title: CBT behavioral activation applied to management
quotes.text: I mean, I have a list of myself. I've got a list on my phone of my behavioral activations, and it's things that I know I can do if I start feeling like the walls are closing around me, if I feel myself getting sucked into very low mood or negative thinking, or whatever it is.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A concrete tactic practitioners can copy immediately: pre-commit to a personal “activation list” for when you spiral.

quotes.topic_title: CBT behavioral activation applied to management
quotes.text: So behavioral activation just conceptually is, how are you taking action to reverse the downward feeling or the negative feeling that you're feeling? And then the take a punch concept is that applied in the context of I'm in a working environment.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Defines the core framework and shows how to translate a CBT technique into a workplace/management methodology.

quotes.topic_title: CBT behavioral activation applied to management
quotes.text: I think especially for product people who are... So much of their self identity is wrapped up in having the answers, being competent, getting things done.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Pinpoints a common root cause of stress/burnout in product roles that managers can proactively design around.

quotes.topic_title: Second-order benefits: confidence to speak up
quotes.text: But I actually think it's a bigger deal because I see so many people who don't put themselves out there because they're afraid of how it's going to go.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Frames “taking a punch” as primarily about reducing avoidance behavior, not just handling crises.

quotes.topic_title: Second-order benefits: confidence to speak up
quotes.text: This is how you get on people's radar as somebody who's like, "Oh, that person's got great ideas, thinks about things the right way," whatever it is.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Connects speaking up in meetings directly to career acceleration and visibility.

quotes.topic_title: Second-order benefits: confidence to speak up
quotes.text: first of all, every additional person in a meeting has a cost, because every additional person in a meeting makes the people in that meeting less candid than they would have been if there were fewer people in that meeting.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Counterintuitive meeting design principle: adding observers reduces candor and decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Second-order benefits: confidence to speak up
quotes.text: It's really important that you earn your place in this meeting and let's work on how to do that.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Actionable standard for meeting participation: justify attendance by contributing value.

quotes.topic_title: Second-order benefits: confidence to speak up
quotes.text: And so if you can help people be less afraid of that, that's 90% of the challenge of actually improving some of these skills.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A practical diagnosis: fear reduction is the main lever for improving communication and contribution.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: too many PMs play easy mode
quotes.text: if you are really in it just for pure love of the game, you just love product management, why are you building products for people exactly like you who have all your exact same at a company that sells to other companies that doesn't worry about pricing?
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Challenges PMs to examine whether they’re choosing comfortable, self-referential problems instead of harder, more consequential ones.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: too many PMs play easy mode
quotes.text: in the grand scheme of things, I wish that the people who have this pure love of product management and have this pure love of building things that you would see more of that applied to building for low income people, building for social services, things like that, that really, really need that kind of work.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A direct call to apply product craft to high-stakes domains where good product work can materially improve lives.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: too many PMs play easy mode
quotes.text: And I think there's a level of prestige obviously associated with working in certain companies, and you get less of that in other industries. And so people would naturally gravitate toward that.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Names “prestige” as a hidden incentive shaping career and product choices, often pulling builders away from impact-heavy work.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: too many PMs play easy mode
quotes.text: I know there's a ton of people out there doing really, really important work in really, really hard spaces, and I see you and I appreciate it and shout out to you.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Reinforces that meaningful product work exists outside prestigious companies and validates practitioners operating in difficult environments.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency: teaching how leaders think
quotes.text: And it makes things super inefficient. I think people will often say like, "Oh, it's a process problem." It's not a process problem. It's not approval problem. I think it's a transparency and it's communication problem, like downward communication, outward communication.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Reframes slow approvals as a transparency/communication issue rather than a process flaw, pointing to a more leverageable fix.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency: teaching how leaders think
quotes.text: And so what is much more helpful than understanding what your CEO thinks is, I think understanding how your CEO thinks.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Introduces a mental-model shift: teach decision-making patterns, not just decisions, to unlock autonomy and speed.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency: teaching how leaders think
quotes.text: And when I feel confident that people on my team understand how I think, I don't need to read their emails, I don't need to approve things.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Connects leader transparency directly to eliminating approval bottlenecks and increasing team independence.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency: teaching how leaders think
quotes.text: And I try to make an effort every week. I don't always do it, but I try to send my team just a quick rundown in Slack of, "Here are the most important conversations or the most interesting conversations I had this week. Here's what that person said verbatim."
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable tactic for cascading context from key meetings to help teams calibrate decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency: teaching how leaders think
quotes.text: "And here's what I interpret that as. Here's why I think they say that. Here's where I think that's coming from and here's what I'm going to do differently as a result."
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Provides a simple template for turning raw meeting notes into shared interpretation and action, teaching how leaders think.

quotes.topic_title: When you disagree with leadership decisions
quotes.text: First, I do try to go through the what if I'm wrong exercise.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A simple self-check framework for approaching leadership decisions you disagree with before pushing back or escalating.

quotes.topic_title: When you disagree with leadership decisions
quotes.text: But whatever it is, I really try to get to the bottom of, let me really make sure that I have done my best to understand this person's point of view.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Emphasizes doing the work to uncover the underlying rationale (including hidden constraints) before forming a final stance.

quotes.topic_title: When you disagree with leadership decisions
quotes.text: And so I think what I try to do in those situations is separate out my opinion from it, from the, " Well, what is the insight that makes it make sense to this person" and explain their rationale.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A practical method for representing a decision credibly: distinguish your view from the decision-maker’s mental model and communicate that model to the team.

quotes.topic_title: When you disagree with leadership decisions
quotes.text: Let's find out. We're not going to find out if we are all squabbling about whether this is a good idea the whole time. The only way we're going to find out is if we give it the best shot that we have and try to do it.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Reframes disagreement as an execution-and-learning problem: align on running the experiment well to discover what’s true.

quotes.topic_title: When you disagree with leadership decisions
quotes.text: Yeah. Because I think in product, I like to joke, there's no right answers. Right? There's only wrong answers, and you're just trying to execute well on the least wrong answer that's available to you.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: A contrarian mental model that reduces false certainty and encourages teams to focus on strong execution amid ambiguity.

quotes.topic_title: Magic questions: statements ending in “agree?”
quotes.text: I talk about what I like to call the magic questions, but the thing about magic questions is they're not actually questions, they're statements and they end with, "Do you agree?" Or "Is that right?"
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Defines a concrete technique for eliciting someone’s mental model by turning questions into testable statements.

quotes.topic_title: Magic questions: statements ending in “agree?”
quotes.text: I have found this, the most helpful way for kind of trying to understand a person's mental model is to just put facts in front of them and see what they say no to and what they say yes to.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Actionable method: learn faster by probing accept/reject boundaries instead of inviting vague explanations.

quotes.topic_title: Magic questions: statements ending in “agree?”
quotes.text:
And so I learned that if I kind of flip that and approached that, "Well, what if we did X, Y, and Z?

What if this is what it looked like? What if this is what the copy said? Would that be okay?" No, yes. If no, why? If yes, why?
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Provides a practical script (especially for legal/compliance) to replace “it depends” loops with concrete scenarios.

quotes.topic_title: Magic questions: statements ending in “agree?”
quotes.text: So they're actually forcing themselves to make this assertion. And then they're kind of calibrating how close that was to how I would think about it, which will get you much faster, much further than just asking open-ended questions and getting the answer.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Explains why this approach accelerates learning: it builds judgment calibration rather than dependency on answers.

quotes.topic_title: Magic questions: statements ending in “agree?”
quotes.text: Well, you got to go in pure of heart. You've got to go in open to being wrong and even expected to be wrong. And you have to make that clear to them.
quotes.speaker: Hilary Gridley
quotes.context: Counterbalances the “agree?” tactic with a key constraint: it only works when paired with humility to avoid coercion and bad intel.
